caption:
This photograph depicts a forest scene primarily divided into two contrasting areas: a dense stand of upright conifer trees on one side and an area strewn with felled trees and debris on the other. The left side of the image shows tall, straight trees with dark trunks and sparse foliage, extending upwards and occupying roughly half of the frame. These trees are illuminated by sunlight and convey a sense of healthy, undisturbed forest.

In stark contrast, the right half of the image is filled with chaos and destruction. This side shows numerous logs and branches haphazardly piled on the ground, hinting at recent logging activities. The felled trees vary in size and are covered in places by smaller twigs and debris. This devastated area evokes a sense of disruption and environmental impact, demonstrating the aftermath of intensive forestry practices.

Above this scene, the sky is visible and appears clear and sunny, highlighting the starkness of the deforestation. The background hints at a continuing forest beyond the immediate scene, suggesting that the area pictured might be part of a larger forested region undergoing similar treatment.

The overall composition contrasts the natural vertical lines of the intact forest with the horizontal disorder of the logged area, creating a powerful visual narrative about human intervention and its effects on natural environments.
title: The edge of a freshly cut clear-cut with a Douglas fir tree fallen and ready to be yarded in the foreground and Douglas firs standing on the edge of the clear-cut in timberland Vancouver Island, British Columbia. From the Environmental Protection Agency's Project DOCUMERICA, ENTHEOS. "In Praise of Forests". For additional images see fiche #s 209, 210, 211, 212, and 213. Summer, 1974.
